title: Who will win the election for New York's 11th Congressional District in 2020?
preds: Backlash against BLM increasing Republican support.

Two recent Marist polls show this race is neck and neck with each candidate winning by just a few points in one. While the incumbent still holds the advantage in my mind, it is a much smaller advantage than it originally appeared.
NY is experiencing high turnout, favoring the Republican candidate in  Staten Island.

https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2020-election-forecast/house/new-york/11/ Note to self: you moved Dem win lower then moved it back when 538 failed to follow. Don't do that next time! Especially if you are personally familiar with the race. Also, if the failure to move is due not to new polls but to lack of polls.
The 11th has a lot of police and apparently Trump propaganda that the Dems will defund the police is cutting through.  Edging down to meet consensus.

Est. 70/30 Dem with 30% chance of flipping.  Going in harder on the basis that small 'c' conservatives who might otherwise vote Republican, as the 11th has in previous years, don't, generally, enjoy chaos, and chaos is what the Republican leadership now represents. https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/our-forecast-thinks-democrats-will-keep-the-house-and-maybe-even-gain-seats/

Base rate for incumbents is 90%+ [1]. Also, 90%+ for candidates who outraise their opponents [2]. Knicks owner Jim Dolan may be donating $50,000 out of spite [3] but Rose's cash on hand advantage is more than $3,000,000 [4]. [1] https://www.opensecrets.org/elections-overview/reelection-rates
[2] https://www.opensecrets.org/elections-overview/winning-vs-spending?cycle=2020

It is closer than this forecast predicts so I am backing off a tad. Freshman Democrat Max Rose has carved out a role as a vocal, moderate critic of his party’s liberal wing – a posture that could help him in a tough race against Republicans' 2017 nominee for mayor of New York City, Nicole Malliotakis.
No way the GOP wins this seat.

Democratic chances are overstated by crowd forecast, because:
1) District has a Cook partisan lean of R+3
2) The mailed-in ballots were a mess in June, which gives GOP a boost, since disproportionate numbers of Democratic voters use that method: https://theintercept.com/2020/07/16/new-york-mail-in-ballots-thrown-out/
3) Max Rose is only a 1st-term Congressman, so his incumbency advantage is low.
4) District voted for Trump in 2016.
5) GOP candidate has a solid resume and is considered a moderate, so an ideological fit for the district. I put this more at 50/50.
Rich people will not be pleased about the econonmy and how the republicans have handled the last four years

NYC is royal blue but after recent results have been knocked on their butts. However, habit is a habit. Staten Island is different though. While its apart of NYC most people consider it an afterthought and could easily go Republican.

NY currently has six House Republicans out of 27 districts. 
Congressional District 11 – Staten Island and Southern Kings County (Brooklyn)
CPVI of R+3 In the 2016 Presidential Election:
NY State – Clinton 59.5% / Trump 39.8%
NYC – Clinton 79.8% / Trump 18%
NY State (outside of NYC) – Clinton 48.4% / Trump 47.4%
Richmond County – Trump 56% / Clinton 41% (2012 – Obama 50.7% / Romney 41% - CPVI of R+6)
District 11 – Trump 54% / Clinton 44% Max Rose has run and won in one election versus Republican Incumbent Donovan in 2018 winning in an upset – 53% to 47% (192,038 votes). Kings County accounted for 27.5% of the overall vote (Rose 59.8%/Donovan 39.7%) and Richmond County accounted for 72.5% of the overall vote (Rose 50.5% / Donovan 49.2%). Donovan had won his prior election by a wide margin in a special election that only garnered 42,569 votes where he lost Kings County but carried Richmond County by a wide margin. Nicole Malliotakis has run for State Assembly five times. In 2010 she defeated two time incumbent Hyer-Spencer by a 52% to 42% margin (26,705 votes in total). She lost the vote in Kings County but won by a wide margin in Richmond County. In 2012 she defeated local deli owner John Mancuso 55% to 35% (38,004 votes) again losing Kings County but winning Richmond County by a wide margin. In 2014 she defeated Marybeth Melendez by a margin of 71% to 26% (21,147 votes) this time winning a close race in Kings County and again winning Richmond County by a wide margin. In 2016 she ran uncontested to retain her seat. In 2018, she beat Adam Baumel by a margin of 60% to 40% (34,731 votes). She lost the vote in Kings County and again won by a wide margin in Richmond County. In 2017, she lost in a mayoral bid to Bill DeBlasio by a wide margin, but garnered about 70% of the votes cast in her district. Both candidates beat an incumbent to win their seats. Rose in an apparent upset and Malliotakis in an even race. Rose’s win was on a much larger scale than Malliotakis, who is by all accounts, a rising star in the local Republican party. Both candidates are more moderate for their respective parties, however Rose only voted with Trump 7.5% of the time so far during his stint in Washington.  Rose is against defunding the policy and Malliotakis is “neither pro-life or pro-choice”, however has voted against transgender bathrooms and is against NY being a sanctuary city and providing driver licenses for illegal residents. Malliotakis has been endorsed by Trump, which is debatable whether this will help or hurt her. Borough President James Oddo (Republican) has not made an endorsement and has work with Rose on many public endeavors.  Through the end of June, Rose has raised more than double the amount of Malliotakis ($5.7M to $1.8M). Bottom Line: Rose is a moderate that plays to both sides of the aisle. Malliotakis is less moderate and has been dubbed a rising star within the Republican party but has yet to face a tough challenger outside of her failed mayoral bid in 2017. Kings County will undoubtedly go to Rose, but he will need at least an even showing in Richmond County against the native Malliotakis to win.
PredictIt, rated tossup by the major election handicappers (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York%27s_11th_congressional_district).
Rose has very poor approval in his district
Should go Dem but lots of talk around this being to close to call?
The Democratic challenger won in a rout in 2018. This is not likley the year to gain that seat back on Staten Island.

Rose was first elected in 2018, winning by a 6-point margin. The district was one of only 30 that flipped after voting for Trump in 2016 to a blue congressional seat. This means Rose is not only an incumbent, but has momentum. However, the first challenge to a congressional seat is often seen as the hardest to endure and overcome. Real Clear Politics has this as a toss-up, but I'd say the Dem incumbent has a marginal advantage.
Rose flipped a traditionally Republican district in 2018 on the strength of the public's dislike for the President. Things haven't improved for the President since then.

This is a very interesting district. Trump "only" won this R stronghold 56/41 in 2016 - he underperformed Donovan, the R House candidate by about 5%. Rose won on Staten Island and the small portion of Brooklyn covered by NY11, massively improving on the results from 2016. Is this district becoming reliably D or will Trump pull it back to R? This is the kind of suburban district that Trump has  looked increasingly weak in, but it is also a district with a disproportionate # of law enforcement officers and others who fit the "law and order" side of the R party - will they come out strong in repudiation of the BLM movement? I think Rose can win - he has a $ advantage - but if Trump wins, Rose likely loses.

The 11th had a brief flirtation with the Rs which is now over.   The Ds will take Manhattan, the Bronx, and Staten Island, too.  It's lovely going through the zoo....   Look it up:   Rogers & Hart, I think, some time in the 1920s.
